subsubsection.title: Use negative exponents
subsubsection.p: Recall that a negative exponent indicates a reciprocal.

li.p: Raise each factor to the power -2. Multiply exponents: (2bc^{-3})^{-2} = 2^{-2}b^{-2}(c^{-3})^{-2} = \dfrac{c^6}{4b^2}
We cannot add or subtract powers with different exponents. 3x^{-4}-2x^{-3} = \dfrac{3}{x^4} - \dfrac{2}{x^3}

statement.p: Simplify where possible. Write your answer without negative exponents. (2x^3y^{-4})(\dfrac{3}{4}x^{-2}y^2)
Simplify where possible. Write your answer without negative exponents. ~\dfrac{ab^{-3}}{(3ab)^{-2}}
Simplify where possible. Write your answer without negative exponents. 2x^{-2}-(2x)^{-2}
Simplify where possible. Write your answer without negative exponents. 2x^{-2}(-2x)^{-2}

subsubsection.title: Improper fractions
subsubsection.p: An improper fraction is one in which the numerator is larger than the denominator.

statement.p: Write an improper fraction for the sum ~2 + \dfrac{3}{8}

solution.p: We write the whole number with the same denominator as the fraction. Thus, \blert{2} + \dfrac{3}{8} = \blert{\dfrac{16}{8}}+\dfrac{3}{8} = \dfrac{16+3}{8} = \dfrac{19}{8}

statement.p: Write an improper fraction for the difference ~3 - \dfrac{1}{5}

solution.p: We write the whole number with the same denominator as the fraction. Thus, \blert{3} - \dfrac{1}{5} = \blert{\dfrac{15}{5}}-\dfrac{1}{5} = \dfrac{15-1}{5} = \dfrac{14}{5}

subsubsection.title: Check a division
subsubsection.p: Remember that division is the inverse operation for multiplication.

statement.p: Check that the division is correct: ~536\div 15 = 35\dfrac{11}{15}

solution.p: The quotient tells us that 15 divides into 536 thirty-five times, with a remainder of 11. This in turn means that if we multiply 15 by 35, and then add 11, we should get 536 back again. 15 \times 35 + 11 = 525 + 11 = 536 Note the pattern: divisor \times quotient + remainder = starting number

statement.p: Check that the division is correct: (3n^2+n-6)\div (n+2) = 3n-5 + \dfrac{4}{n+2}

solution.p: The answer tells us that n+2 divides into 3n^2+n-6 to give a quotient of 3n-5, with a remainder of 4. If we multiply n+2 by 3n-5, and then add 4, we should get 3n^2+n-6 back again. (n+2)(3n-5)+4 = (3n^2+n-10)+4 = 3n^2-n-6
